resources.string: Imprecise language leads to imprecise thought.

Bookshelf is the root node of the Analysis perspective in the Context frame. It provides a place to store Notebooks.

Anyone can create a bookshelf, usually for their personal use.

Bookshelves are automatically sequenced in an alpha sort of the bookshelf headline.

Notebooks on a bookshelf are automatically sequenced in an alpha sort of the notebook headline.

Notebooks on a bookshelf may also appear on other bookshelves, and frequently do.

When a bookshelf is deleted, the notebooks which do not appear on any other bookshelf may be moved, orphaned, or deleted.

Orphaned notebooks appear on a special "Orphans" bookshelf, which should be periodically cleaned up by deleting the orphan Notebooks or moving them to another bookshelf where they will be used.
Community Member Flywheel Team Governance Authority
Facilitation Issue Link To Work Task

Fiscal Year is the root node of the Strategic Planning perspective and the Work Planning perspective. It provides a 12 month "time box" within which to plan the activities of an organization and measure success.

Fiscal Years are always sorted by the year number, ascending. Year number cannot be changed, and duplicates cannot be created.

Fiscal Years can only be created and deleted by the Facilitator of the FMM (Flywheel Management Model).

In the Strategic Planning perspective, Fiscal Year contains all of the organization's Strategic Milestones for that year.

In the Work Planning perspective, Fiscal Year contains the Cadences for that year. These are a smaller time box (frequently 3 weeks) within which commitments are made to complete Work Packages.

When a Fiscal Year is deleted, all of its Cadences and their content are also deleted. At the option of the user, the Strategic Milestones for that year may be deleted, orphaned, or moved to another Fiscal Year.

Fiscal Years start in January by default. The starting month is established when the FMM (Flywheel Management Model) is created, and cannot be changed (in the Community Edition).

Project is a collection of Strategic Assets and Project assets
which should be treated as a cohesive package for purposes of:
- governance and facilitation
• budgeting
• staffing
• work breakdown
• work planning
• leveraging domain knowledge

The primary purpose of the Project is to complete Strategic Assets in support of one or (usually) more Strategic Milestones.

Project Assets are identified, sequenced, and completed as needed to support the Strategic Assets.

Project Assets are identified, sequenced, and completed, within the scope of a Project, as needed to support the Strategic Assets being delivered by that Project.

If the target Strategic Asset is not completed, any completed Project Assets represent meaningful current or future value to the organization which should be managed and leveraged.

A Project Asset may also be subsequently identified as strategic, and promoted to Strategic Asset in a Strategic Milestone.
Project Asset Link To Work Package
Service Request Link To Work Task

Strategic Assets are just strategic Project Assets. Strategic Assets are the stakeholder and/or customer "ask" during Strategic Planning. They represent specific assets which are required to achieve a Strategic Milestone.

A Strategic Asset can belong to only 1 Strategic Milestone.

A Strategic Assets are always created from the context of a Strategic Milestone. They can either be a brand new asset, or an existing Project Asset that is identified as critical to the success of the Milestone.

When Strategic Assets are orphaned, they become Project Assets.
Work Package Link To Work Task

Flywheel Story Editor™ (FSE) enables the rapid voice (and keyboard) capture of structured text.

An FSE document includes the Story, Notes, History (including all previous versions of the document), and details about the Community of people who participated in creation of the document.

Users can also see the history of each paraphraph while editing the Story and Notes section.

FSE documents are created for an FMM (Flywheel Management Model) node to:
 • capture requirements and specifications
 • capture a narrative
 • capture key elements of a conversation
 • facilitate a collaboration session
 • organizally capture document consensus (paragraph locking)
 • create a historical document
 • captures lessons learned

FSE documents can be shared using the "Publish PDF" menu option. The publishing wizard provides options on which document sections should be published, and the publishing destination. Destinations for the PDF file include any combination of a Dropbox folder, HpEprint printer, and email recipients. An additional note may be included with the emailed PDF.

Story is the 1st of 4 sections of a Flywheel Story Editor™ (FSE) document. Each FMM (Flywheel Management Model) node can have a Story, and most should.

A Story captures the 'who', 'what' and 'why' of an FMM node. At a minimum, it should include what you (and the rest of the room) were thinking at the time you created the FMM node, supplementing the Headline of the node.

The story should always be of sufficient quality and completeness to share with the Sponsor or Customer in an ad-hoc meeting or during a chance hallway conversation. It should always be the basis for answering questions from sponsors, customers or other stakeholders such as:
 • What is this FMM node?
 • Why should we care?
 • What other people/stakeholders should care?
 • Who can help us make this complete?
 • What are the special challenges?
 • What are the special opportunities?

The story should continually evolve as new information is discovered and shared. Whenever a conversation or line of questioning turns to a specific FMM node, whether in a meeting or a hallway conversation, you should immediately open that story on your tablet and be ready to capture all new information and/or questions. The Flywheel Dictation Keyboard™ makes it very easy to focus on the conversation at hand, while capturing well structured text for high-fidelity editing at a later time.

The story should be long enough to cover the subject, but short enough to hold the attention of the reader. It should only contain information that is appropriate to share with stakeholders outside the team (but still inside the organization or trusted partners). Information that is more informal, speculative, unconfirmed, or not for general consumption, should instead be added to the Notes section of the FSE document.

There are 2 common mistakes when authoring a story:
 • Including details in the story which should more appropriately, and
 usefully, appear in the stories for child nodes of this Fmm node
 • Including content that should more appripriately be included in Notes,
 at least until such time as the information can be confirmed

Stories should be well organized, well structured, and properly sequenced; taking full advantage of the highly efficient paragraph styling and sequencing features of FSE. Remember, the story is the public face of the FMM node and should be easily digestable and understood by a wide audience of stakeholders (as well as those who must do the actual work).

Stories should be of sufficient quality to look good when included in a formal presentation, project document, or as an attachment to an RFP or other contractual document. Maintaining good stories will keep you from wasting any time repackaging this information for these other purposes, and enable you to be instantly responsive to such requests.

FSE's paragraph locking feature should be used to manage and document the evolving consensus around a Story (and optionally Notes). This is a great way to incrementally "lock down" a document for sign-off as it matures.

As with Notes, FSE maintains a complete history of who has edited the Story, when, and what they specifically changed (or deleted). All prior versions of the Story can be viewed and recovered.
